block.p: In two recent articles -- ''After Sanctions, Doctors Get Drug Company Pay'' (front page, June 3) and ''Psychiatrists, Troubled Children and Drug Industry's Role'' (front page, May 10) -- you focused on psychiatrists in Minnesota, presumably because it's the one state with a robust law on disclosing pharmaceutical company payments to physicians.

In two recent articles -- ''After Sanctions, Doctors Get Drug Company Pay'' (front page, June 3) and ''Psychiatrists, Troubled Children and Drug Industry's Role'' (front page, May 10) -- you focused on psychiatrists in Minnesota, presumably because it's the one state with a robust law on disclosing pharmaceutical company payments to physicians.
These articles raise important issues of concern to all of us: the influence of big business on health care.
I have met many psychiatrists, the vast majority of whom, like me, haven't taken pharmaceutical money. We support full and honest disclosure. Our primary focus is our patients' well-being.

The people I know are genuinely caring, hard-working doctors who chose to go into psychiatry to help people. They and their patients deserve to have that fact known. A June 2006 salary survey, for example, looked at pay for 59 medical specialties and found that psychiatrists ranked 48th. That's hardly a picture of greed.
Jeff Hardwig, M.D. International Falls, Minn. June 5, 2007
The writer is president of the Minnesota Psychiatric Society.
